datafield.subfield: James of Viterbo's Quodlibeta, Books I, II, and IV (ff. 1-90); the manuscript misidentifies Book IV as Book III. The works of pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite (ff. 91-121) were added later and are written on irregular scraps of parchment.

1. ff. 1ra-37rb: [Disputatio prima de quolibet] / James of Viterbo -- 2. ff. 37rb-73vb: [Disputatio secunda de quolibet] / James of Viterbo -- 3. ff. 74ra-74va: [Untitled text]; incipit: "[U]trum el[ement]a manea[n]t i[n] mixto q[uantu]m ad suas s[u]b[stanti]as [et] n[atur]as..." -- 4. ff. 75ra-89rb: [Disputatio quarta de quolibet] / James of Viterbo -- 5. ff. 89va-90va: [Untitled text]; incipit: "[U]trum for[m]a s[u]bsta[nti]al[is] i[n]troducat[ur] succe[ssi]ve..." -- 6. ff. 91r-96v: De celesti ierarchia / Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite -- 7. ff. 97r-104v: De ecclesiastica ierarchia / Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite -- 8. ff. 105r-118r: De divinis nominibus / Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite -- 9. ff. 118r-118v: De mystica theologia / Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite -- 10. ff. 118v-121r: [Epistole] / Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite. -- 11. ff. 121r-121v: [Accessus ad Dionysium Areopagitam] / Anon.

Fols. 1-72 are numbered (in medieval Arabic numerals) to correspond with the quodlibetal question that appears on that folio; many of these numerals, which appear in the upper right corner of the recto side, have been mutilated by trimming. The absence of such numeration from fols. 73-90 may be due to trimming.
Fol. 104 has been torn, with the loss of some text.
Layout: Fols. 1-90 written in 2 columns of 44 lines; fols. 91-121 written in as many as 65 long lines, with much variation.
Script: Gothic textual, several hands. The letter-forms in fols. 91-121 show chancery influence and cursive tendencies.
Decoration: Fols. 1-90 contain large illuminated initials and smaller initials in red or blue with red or violet flourishes. Fols. 91-121 are not decorated.

Binding: Modern, paper with leather straps. The manuscript was rebound by P. Verhegen on 8/2/1994. The previous binding has not been preserved; Calkins states that it consisted of 18th-century vellum, stamped with the initials "W.D.B." and the date "1701". It would therefore share the same provenance as Misc. Bd. Ms. 2 (Quinque Platonicae sapientiae claves / Marsilio Ficino), which bears the same initials and date stamped on a white vellum wrapper.
Accompanying materials: three leaves of Latin transcription in modern cursive hands.

Origin: Fols. 1-90 were written in Fabriano, Italy by a certain William who belonged to the same religious order as James of Viterbo (Ordo Eremitarum Sancti Augustini), 14th century (see fol. 90v). The scripts contained in fols. 91-121 are not typically Italian, and it is not known when the two manuscripts were first bound together.

Provenance: W.D.B. (1701) -- according to the old covers, which are no longer extant, but reported by Calkins. Bought by George Lincoln Burr for the White Library, from Tregaskis, London (Cat. 242, no. 16; May 1893).
Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library, Misc. Bd. Ms. 39.
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare BX J17
De Ricci, S. Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada,

II, p. 1227; Calkins, R.G. Illuminated Manuscripts, p. 19, no. 7; Ypma, E. Jacobi de Viterbio O.E.S.A. Disputatio Prima de Quolibet, p. x; Ypma, E. Jacobi de Viterbio O.E.S.A. Disputatio Quarta de Quolibet, pp. vi-vii.

1. Jacobi de Viterbio O.E.S.A. Disputatio Prima de Quolibet, ed. E. Ypma, Würzburg-Rome, 1968; 2. Jacobi de Viterbio O.E.S.A. Disputatio Secunda de Quolibet, ed. E. Ypma, Würzburg, 1969; 4. Jacobi de Viterbio O.E.S.A. Disputatio Quarta de Quolibet, ed. E. Ypma, Würzburg-Rome, 1975; 6. Patrologia latina 122:1037-1070; 7. Patrologia latina 122:1069-1112; 8. Patrologia latina 122:1115-1172; 9. Patrologia latina 122:1171-1176; 10. Patrologia latina 122:1177-1194.
The present manuscript was used by Eelcko Ypma in his edition of the Disputatio Quarta of James of Viterbo (1975), but not in his editions of the earlier books.
Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections.
